title: Top London DJ left paralysed by huge tumour weeks after release of debut record | London Evening Standard
text:
Sunday 5 February 2017 07:31 BST Click to followThe Evening Standard Rising star: Mr Smith, known as DJ Daredevil, has performed at some of London's most popular nightclubs Ben Smith 
A top DJ who has performed at popular London nightclubs has revealed he may never walk again after he was diagnosed with cancer weeks after his debut record was released. 
Ben Smith, also known as DJ Daredevil, was admitted to St Barts Hospital four days before Christmas after severe swelling on his legs and ankles left him paralysed from the waist down. 
The award-winning artist, from Stoke Newington, was diagnosed with Burkitt's Lymphoma, an aggressive rare form of non-Hodgkin lymphoma after a large tumour was identified in his back. 
It means Mr Smith is now undergoing an intense course of chemotherapy as he fights to beat the disease and resume his burgeoning career. 
The 38-year-old has earned himself a glowing reputation among DJs following collaborations with US stars Pete Rock, CL Smooth, Jazzy Jeff and Big Daddy Kane. Paralysed: Ben Smith was diagnosed with an aggressive form of cancer just before Christmas (Ben Smith) 
He has also performed sets at some of London’s top nightclubs including Scala, Bungalow 8 and the O2 Forum in Kentish Town. 
In November, Mr Smith released his first record after he produced Represent to the Fullest with Baltimore rapper Ill Conscious. 
But despite his rising star status, tragedy struck when Mr Smith was rushed to hospital with unbearable pain later diagnosed as cancer. 
He said: “As you can imagine it was a massive shock. I felt like I was on the path to a really successful career and then this happened to me. An urgent fundraiser has raised nearly £9,000 to support Mr Smith through his cancer battle (Ben Smith) 
“I may never be able to walk again but it affects everyone differently. Maybe with some rehabilitation I can." 
And despite his debilitating illness Mr Smith said he was confident he can continue his career. 
“Music is my life whether I’m performing or just at home and even if I don’t have the full use of my legs I’m confident I will be behind the set again,” he said. 
A fundraising page was launched last month to help Mr Smith cover accommodation, disability adaptions, equipment, care and living costs. Top DJ: Mr Smith recently released his first record before he was struck down with the disease (Ben Smith) 
So far, nearly £9,000 has been raised in just over two weeks towards a £10,000 target set by Mr Smith’s brother Matt, another London-based DJ. Read more
